new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017 customization required 35 hours from undergraduate student programmer plus 4 hours from staff
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: For the first season of use (2017), creating the Map Digitisation customisation of FAIMS Mobile required 35 h from an undergraduate student programmer plus 4 h from staff (Nassif-Haynes et al., 2021).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017 in-field setup required 3 hours from staff
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Setup of the server and configuration of the client devices in the field required 3 h from staff.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017 map preparation required about 1.5 hours
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017 file compression, upload, and download took 2.5 hours
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Monitoring file compression, upload to the server, and download to devices took an additional 2.5 h.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017 training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2018 validation addition took 1 hour of programmer development time
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: For the second season, adding additional validation to ensure population of latitude and longitude from GPS (see 'Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records' below) took 1 h of development from the programmer.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2018 in-field setup required 1 hour (reusing same equipment and system)
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: In-field set-up required an hour (reusing the same equipment and system as the previous year), map preparation 30 min, file preparation and transfer 1.5 h, and student training and supervision another 30 min.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2018 map preparation: 30 minutes
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: In-field set-up required an hour (reusing the same equipment and system as the previous year), map preparation 30 min, file preparation and transfer 1.5 h, and student training and supervision another 30 min.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2018 file preparation and transfer: 1.5 hours
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: In-field set-up required an hour (reusing the same equipment and system as the previous year), map preparation 30 min, file preparation and transfer 1.5 h, and student training and supervision another 30 min.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2018 student training and supervision: 30 minutes
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: In-field set-up required an hour (reusing the same equipment and system as the previous year), map preparation 30 min, file preparation and transfer 1.5 h, and student training and supervision another 30 min.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Across both seasons: total 51 hours including 36 hours from programmer and 15 from project staff
new_evidence_items.evidence_type: time measurement - total customization and setup
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Across both seasons, customisation, setup, and supervision took about 51 h, including 36 h from the programmer and 15 from project staff.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Initial customization and setup time before fieldwork: 44 hours
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Of this time, initial customisation and setup time before fieldwork was 44 h, while the time required during fieldwork to prepare and distribute maps, and then supervise participants, was 7 h.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Time required during fieldwork to prepare, distribute maps, and supervise: 7 hours
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Of this time, initial customisation and setup time before fieldwork was 44 h, while the time required during fieldwork to prepare and distribute maps, and then supervise participants, was 7 h.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Post-fieldwork accuracy checking of 4 randomly selected maps (7% of total) required 6 hours of staff time
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Finally, re-examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017: 125.8 person-hours volunteer time concentrated across five rainy days, 8,343 features digitised from 42 maps (~17,000 sq km)
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: In 2017, it was used for a total of 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017 average time per record: 54 seconds (based on device-recorded start/end times, excluding pauses)
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: The average time to record a point feature was 54 s, based on start and end times of feature creation as recorded by the devices (representing work time excluding pauses between records).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2018: 63.6 person-hours volunteer time, 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (~6,500 sq km), average rate 92 seconds per record
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: In 2018, use was more sporadic; participants who stayed at the base for any reason sometimes undertook digitisation. The system was used for 63.6 person-hours, with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km), an average rate of one record every 92 s.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Total: 10,827 point features in 189.4 student-hours (63 seconds per record average)
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: In total, 10,827 point features, mostly burial and settlement mounds, were recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 s per record).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 58 map tiles representing about 23,500 sq km were digitised
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Fifty-eight map tiles representing about 23,500 sq km were digitised.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Dataset contained as many as 119,097 discrete values (10,827 records Ã— up to 11 attribute-value pairs)
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Since a single point record could be associated with 11 attribute-value pairs, the dataset contained as many as 119,097 discrete values (many captured automatically).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017 concentrated digitisation was more productive than 2018 intermittent work, but both seasons yielded large valuable datasets with little supervision
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: The concentrated digitisation in 2017 was more productive than the intermittent work of 2018, but both seasons yielded large and valuable datasets utilising time that might otherwise have been lost (e.g., to inclement weather), while requiring little supervision by project staff.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2010 desktop GIS effort produced 915 features and required about 5-7 hours of staff training, support, and error-checking over three weeks
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Although we did not maintain detailed volunteer time-on-task records, we know this effort produced a dataset of 915 features and required about 5â€“7 h of staff training, support, and error-checking over a three-week period (based on our field journals).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2010: Most volunteers did not persevere long enough to repay their initial training time; one persistent student accounted for almost all digitised features
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Most volunteers did not persevere with the activity long enough to repay their initial training time. Indeed, one persistent student accounted for almost all the digitised features; without his perseverance, the digitisation effort would have failed entirely.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Low volunteer attrition indicated satisfaction with the mobile approach experience
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Low volunteer attrition indicated satisfaction with the experience.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Performance degraded once devices exceeded about 2,500 records; GPS coordinate extraction went from 3-5 seconds to 30 seconds
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: In use, automated extraction of coordinates from GPS into the Latitude/Longitude and Northing/Easting fields, which took three to 5 s with an empty database, took as long as 30 s once a device exceeded about 2,500 records.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Performance degradation was mitigated by exporting all data and instantiating a new empty version; aggregation of multiple exports was trivial
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Deteriorating performance was mitigated by exporting all data and instantiating a new and empty version of the application. Since data structures were identical, aggregation of multiple exports was trivial.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Best digitisers could be both fast and accurate, while poorest were neither fast nor accurate
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: The best digitisers, furthermore, could be both fast and accurate, while the poorest digitisers were often neither fast nor accurate (see Tables 1â€“3).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Total recoverable data omissions across both years: 223 (2.06% of records) - 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records), including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2017: 192 records (2.3%) had empty lat/long fields, 17 (0.2%) missing map symbol specification
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Most occurred in 2017 when 192 records (2.3%) had empty latitude and longitude fields and 17 (0.2%) were missing specification of the map symbol.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 2018: Only 13 spatial errors and 1 attribute omission (0.52%) after validation was added
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Spatial omissions were recoverable by re-extracting from geodatabase; only 2 data points could not be recovered
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Since the geodatabase preserved geometries, spatial omissions were corrected by re-extracting latitude and longitude; only two data points could not be recovered.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Quality assurance review of 4 randomly selected maps (7% of total) found 49 errors from true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Second, a review by project staff of four randomly selected maps (7% of the total) found 49 errors from a true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate (see Table 3).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Of 49 errors: 42 were false negatives (missed symbols), 6 were double-marked, 1 classification error, 0 false positives
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Forty-two of these errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students). Six were double-marked (Student C digitised a section of a map twice). Students made only one classification error (a similar symbol mistaken for a benchmark), and no outright false positives.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Individual error rates ranged from 1.3% to 10.6%
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Students' individual error rates ranged from 1.3% to 10.6%.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Two fastest digitisers (44 and 45 s per feature) also had lowest error rates (1.3% and 2.9%); two slowest (61 and 73 s) had highest error rates (10.6% and 7.4%)
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Note that the two fastest digitisers (Students A and B; 44 and 45 s per feature respectively) also had the lowest error rates (1.3 and 2.9%), while the two slowest (Students C and D; 61 and 73 s) had the highest error rates (10.6 and 7.4%).

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: 35 of 49 false negatives were from one student (Student C) failing to digitise three contiguous map sections
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Moreover, 35 of the 49 false negatives were the result of Student C failing to digitise three contiguous sections of an assigned map.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Excluding Student C's outlier performance would have cut cumulative error rate in half to 2.8%
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: These mistakes made his error rate of 10.6% an outlier; excluding Student C would have cut the cumulative error rate in half to 2.8%.

new_evidence_items.evidence_text: Error pattern - mostly false negatives and double-marked features from contiguous sections - made errors relatively easy to identify and correct
new_evidence_items.verbatim_quote: Nevertheless, the overall rate of 5.9% exceeded our expectations. Moreover, the pattern of errors - mostly false negatives and double-marked features, mostly from contiguous map sections - made them relatively easy to identify and correct.

new_claims.claim_text: Total customization, setup, and supervision across both seasons required 51 hours (36 hours programmer, 15 hours staff), with 44 hours before fieldwork and only 7 hours during fieldwork
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Across both seasons, customisation, setup, and supervision took about 51 h, including 36 h from the programmer and 15 from project staff. Of this time, initial customisation and setup time before fieldwork was 44 h, while the time required during fieldwork to prepare and distribute maps, and then supervise participants, was 7 h.

new_claims.claim_text: Customization could be outsourced to junior programmer for modest cost (ca. AUD $2,000), requiring only limited staff time (4-5 hours) for direction
new_claims.verbatim_quote: For the first season of use (2017), creating the Map Digitisation customisation of FAIMS Mobile required 35 h from an undergraduate student programmer plus 4 h from staff (Nassif-Haynes et al., 2021).

new_claims.claim_text: Training and supervision of volunteers required minimal staff time (0.5 hours in 2017, 0.5 hours in 2018) compared to desktop GIS approaches
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.

new_claims.claim_text: Redeployment in year 2 was much faster (1 hour setup vs 3 hours year 1; 0.5 hours map prep vs 1.5 hours year 1), demonstrating scalability
new_claims.verbatim_quote: In-field set-up required an hour (reusing the same equipment and system as the previous year), map preparation 30 min, file preparation and transfer 1.5 h, and student training and supervision another 30 min.

new_claims.claim_text: Quality assurance through accuracy checking was efficient (6 staff hours for 7% sample) and faster than digitizing from scratch
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, re-examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

new_claims.claim_text: 2017 concentrated digitization (5 rainy days) was highly productive: 125.8 person-hours produced 8,343 features from 42 maps at 54 seconds per record
new_claims.verbatim_quote: In 2017, it was used for a total of 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km). The average time to record a point feature was 54 s, based on start and end times of feature creation as recorded by the devices (representing work time excluding pauses between records).

new_claims.claim_text: 2018 sporadic digitization was less efficient (92 seconds per record vs 54 seconds in 2017) but still productive, yielding 2,484 features with minimal supervision
new_claims.verbatim_quote: In 2018, use was more sporadic; participants who stayed at the base for any reason sometimes undertook digitisation. The system was used for 63.6 person-hours, with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km), an average rate of one record every 92 s.

new_claims.claim_text: The mobile crowdsourcing approach met fundamental usability requirements that desktop GIS failed to meet, resulting in low volunteer attrition and high productivity
new_claims.verbatim_quote: By contrast, our customised application met fundamental usability requirements (e.g., Nielsen, 2012), both due to careful design of the customisation itself, and the underlying platform's implementation of Google's Material Design guidelines.

new_claims.claim_text: Low volunteer attrition indicated satisfaction with the mobile digitization experience
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Low volunteer attrition indicated satisfaction with the experience.

new_claims.claim_text: Application performance degraded after ~2,500 records per device but was easily mitigated by exporting data and starting fresh
new_claims.verbatim_quote: In use, automated extraction of coordinates from GPS into the Latitude/Longitude and Northing/Easting fields, which took three to 5 s with an empty database, took as long as 30 s once a device exceeded about 2,500 records. Deteriorating performance was mitigated by exporting all data and instantiating a new and empty version of the application.

new_claims.claim_text: The best digitizers were both fast and accurate, while the poorest were neither fast nor accurate
new_claims.verbatim_quote: The best digitisers, furthermore, could be both fast and accurate, while the poorest digitisers were often neither fast nor accurate (see Tables 1â€“3).

new_claims.claim_text: Recoverable data omissions were low (2.06% overall) and dramatically reduced in year 2 (0.52%) after validation was added
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records), including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions. Most occurred in 2017 when 192 records (2.3%) had empty latitude and longitude fields and 17 (0.2%) were missing specification of the map symbol. Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%).

new_claims.claim_text: Addition of validation between seasons successfully reduced data omissions by 77% (from 2.3% to 0.52%)
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%).

new_claims.claim_text: Overall digitization accuracy was high: 5.87% error rate in quality assurance sample (7% of maps), with individual rates ranging from 1.3% to 10.6%
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Second, a review by project staff of four randomly selected maps (7% of the total) found 49 errors from a true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate (see Table 3).

new_claims.claim_text: Error patterns were predictable and easily correctable: mostly false negatives (missed features) and double-marking from contiguous sections, with one outlier volunteer accounting for most errors
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Moreover, the pattern of errors - mostly false negatives and double-marked features, mostly from contiguous map sections - made them relatively easy to identify and correct. Simple expedients, such as assigning multiple students to digitise the same map tiles independently or assigning one student to review work by another, would likely eliminate most errors.
